verses.verse: ((1 We may not give judgment of our neighbors,6 Nor cast that which is holy unto dogs.13 The broad and strait way.15 False prophets.18 The tree and fruit.24 The house built on a rock,26 and on the sand.) ) Judge (We ought to find fault one with another, but we must beware we do it not without cause, or to seem holier than they, or in hatred of them.) not, that ye be not judged .

For with what (Cross references: : Luke 6:37-38; Rom. 2:1; 1 Cor. 4:3) judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged, and with what (Mark 4:24; Luke 6:38) measure ye mete, it shall be measured unto you again.
And why seest thou the mote, that is in thy brother’s eye, and perceivest not the beam that is in thine own eye?
(Luke 6:41) Or how sayest thou to thy brother, Suffer me to cast out the mote out of thine eye, and behold, a beam is in thine own eye?
Hypocrite, first cast out that beam out of thine own eye, and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother’s eye.

¶ (The stiffnecked and stubborn enemies of the Gospel are unworthy to have it preached unto them.) Give ye not that which is holy to dogs, neither cast ye your (A pearl hath his name among the Grecians, for the orient brightness that is in it: and a pearl was in ancient time in great estimation among the Latins: for a pearl that Cleopatra had, was valued at two hundred and fifty thousand crowns, and the word is now borrowed from that, to signify the most precious heavenly doctrine.) pearls before swine, lest they tread them under their feet, and turning again, all to rent you.

¶ Ask, and it shall be given you: seek, and ye shall find: knock, and it shall be opened unto you. (Prayers are a sure refuge in all miseries.) (Matt. 21:22; Mark 11:24; Luke 11:9; John 24:13; John 16:23; James 1:5)
For whosoever asketh, receiveth: and he that seeketh, findeth: and to him that knocketh, it shall be opened.
For what man is there among you, which if his son ask him bread, would give him a stone?
Or if he ask fish, will he give him a serpent?
If ye then, which are evil, can give to your children good gifts, how much more shall your Father which is in heaven, give good things to them that ask him?

(Luke 6:31; Job 4:16) (A rehearsal of the meaning of the second table.) Therefore whatsoever ye would that men should do to you: even so do ye to them: for this is the (That is to say, the doctrine of the Law and Prophets.) Law and the Prophets.

¶ Enter in at the strait gate: for it is the wide gate, and broad way that leadeth to destruction: and many there be which go in thereat. (Example of life must not be taken from a multitude.) (Luke 13:14)

Because (The way is straight and narrow we must pass through this rough way, and suffer and endure, and be thronged, and to enter into life.) the gate is strait, and the way narrow that leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.
¶ (False teachers must be taken heed of, and they are known by false doctrine and evil living.) Beware of false prophets, which come to you in sheep’s clothing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.
Ye shall know them by their fruits. (Luke 6:44) Do men gather grapes of thorns? or figs of thistles?
So every good tree bringeth forth good fruit, and a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.
A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit.
(Matt. 3:10) Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit, is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
Therefore by their fruits ye shall know them.

¶ (Even the best gifts that are, are nothing without godliness.) Not everyone that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, (Rom. 2:13) but he that doeth my Father’s will which is in heaven.

(James 1:22) Many will say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not by thy (By Name here, is meant that mighty working power of God, which every man witnesseth that calleth upon him.) Name prophesied, and by thy name cast out devils? and by thy name done many (Properly powers: Now these excellent works wrought are called Powers, by occasion of these things which they bring to pass, for by them we understand, how mighty the power of God is.) great works?

And then will I profess to them, I never knew you, (Ps. 6:8) depart from me (You that are given to all kind of wickedness, and seem to make an art of sin.) ye that work iniquity. (This is not of ignorance, but because he will cast them away.) (Luke 13:27)

(True godliness resteth only upon Christ, and therefore always remaineth invincible.) Whosoever then heareth of me these words, (Luke 6:47-48) and doeth the same, I will liken him to a wise man, which hath builded his house on a rock:
And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house, and it fell not: for it was grounded on a rock,
But whosoever heareth these my words, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, which hath builded his house upon the sand:
And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house, and it fell, and the fall thereof was great.
¶ (Mark 4:22; Luke 4:32) And it came to pass, when Jesus had ended these words, the people were astonished at his doctrine.
For he taught them as one having authority, and not as the Scribes.
